Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-552-3662.

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI820201487
Licensee Group Organization: Sisters of Good Shepherd
Licensee Designee: Megan Zambiasi
Chief Administrator: Megan Zambiasi
Agency Name: VISTA MARIA OPEN RESIDENTIAL
Agency Address: 20651 W WARREN ST
DEARBORN HTS, MI 48127-2622

II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
10/30/2023 3:36 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
11/3/23 Face to Face Interviews
11/13/23 PC Interviews
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to Resident Ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
Description direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not provide supervision; therefore, two youth were able to
engage in sexual activity.
Investigation I spoke to Administrator 1 on 10/30/23. Allegations were
discussed. Administrator 1 reported the video revealed there was
1

a lack of supervision. Administrator 1 reported that Youth A and
Youth B were in the bedroom together and were able to sexually
touch each other.
I watched the video dated October 22, 2023. Youth A and Youth B
were in the same bedroom from 8:39pm to 10:54pm. Staff 1 was
in the staff office in the unit and did not visibly check on the youth
during this time frame. Youth came out of the room at 10:54pm.
Interviews
Youth A and Youth B:
Both interviews were conducted on 11/3/23 face to face that the
facility. Youth A reported that she distracted Staff 1 while Youth B
went into her room. Youth B confirmed this in her interview. Youth
reported they had sexual contact. Sexual contact was defined by
both Youth A and Youth B as kissing, rubbing each other’s breast
and behind, as well as toughing each other’s vaginal area. Both
Youth A and Youth B reported it was consensual.
Staff 1:
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 11/13/23. Staff 1
reported that she was working on the unit on 1/0/22/23. Staff 1
reported that she had never worked with this unit before and did
not know the program or the youth that were in the program. Staff
1 reported she has been with the agency for three months. Staff1
reported that she did not complete eye on checks at intervals
throughout the night and did not think that she had to. Staff 1
reported she thought this was like the other unit she has been
working in at the agency.
Staff 2:
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 11/13/23. Staff 2
reported that she worked on the unit with Youth A and Youth B but
she left work at 9:00pm. Staff 2 reported she knows that 15 minute
variable interval checks are to be completed for this unit.
Analysis Staff 1 reported she did not perform variable eye-on checks with
the youth. Video observation confirms this.
Technical Assistance:
Staff reported that she was new and did not know the program
expectations with the unit nor did she know the background
(reason for care, trauma history, diagnosis, behavior cycles, etc.)
of the youth she was serving. The agency is to make sure that
staff are prepared to provide the treatment outlined in their
2

program statement. Having access to the children’s history and
the program statement for the unit they are supervising should be
provided. The agency will need to look into their processes and
staffing to ensure staff know what program they are serving, the
children they are serving and the expectations of that program.
Staff 1 reported she did not do variable interval checks in the
program she usually works with, which is also a requirement. The
agency should make sure that all staff in all of their programs and
licenses are aware of this rule requirement.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation at Vista Maria Open Residential found that Staff 1, a relatively new employee, failed to perform required 15-minute variable interval checks on residents, leaving them unsupervised for over two hours. During this lapse, two youth (Youth A and Youth B) were able to enter a bedroom together and engage in consensual sexual contact. Culpability lies primarily with the facility for inadequate staff training and oversight, as Staff 1 was assigned to an unfamiliar unit without proper knowledge of program rules or resident backgrounds.
